{'cop_index': '0', 'answer': 'Distal renal tubular acidosis', 'why_correct': 'The child presents with vitamin D refractory rickets, low serum phosphate (2.4 mg/dl), and elevated alkaline phosphatase (1040 units). These findings suggest a problem with phosphate metabolism. The normal parathyroid hormone levels indicate no secondary hyperparathyroidism, which is often seen in hypophosphatemic conditions. Distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA) is associated with hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, and normal serum calcium levels, leading to bone issues due to impaired bicarbonate reabsorption. The context supports dRTA as a cause of hypophosphatemia and rickets.', 'why_others_incorrect': "Hypophosphatemic rickets (option1) can present with low phosphate but doesn't explain the normal calcium or the renal acidosis. Vitamin D dependent rickets (option2) would show low 25-OH-D levels, which aren't mentioned. Proximal renal tubular acidosis (option3) causes more severe metabolic acidosis and isn't linked to hypophosphatemia."}
